unnormalised: The monsoon had just begun its insistent drumming on the tin roofs of Mumbai, turning the city into a shimmering, chaotic watercolor. I remember sitting in Mr. Sharma's office, the air thick with humidity and the faint scent of old paper. He was the Senior Manager, Finance at Reliance Industries, a title that felt both weighty and vague to my younger self, fresh out of college and completely unprepared for the corporate world. I was there for an internship, hoping to glean some wisdom, some direction, from the seasoned professionals.

He was the Senior Manager, Finance at Reliance Industries, a title that felt both weighty and vague to my younger self, fresh out of college and completely unprepared for the corporate world. I was there for an internship, hoping to glean some wisdom, some direction, from the seasoned professionals.

unnormalised: Mr. Sharma, a man whose face seemed permanently etched with a look of mild exasperation, was surprisingly patient. He explained, in painstaking detail, the intricacies of the balance sheet, the art of forecasting, and the subtle dance of corporate finance. He was always introduced as Mr. Sharma, never just Sharma, a sign of respect that felt almost old-fashioned in the rapidly modernizing India. He'd often say, "Learn the basics well, beta. No matter what fancy title you achieve later, the fundamentals will always hold you in good stead."

unnormalised: One day, the MD himself, Mr. Ambani (everyone just called him Mr. Ambani, even internally), made an unexpected visit to our floor. The entire office went into a tizzy. Even Mr. Sharma seemed slightly flustered, smoothing down his perfectly combed hair. "He's just the MD," Mr. Sharma mumbled under his breath, but I could see the respect, bordering on reverence, in his eyes.

She wore power suits and spoke with a confidence that both intimidated and inspired me. She told me, "Titles are important, they open doors, but it's your work that keeps them open. Don't get too caught up in designations, focus on delivering results."

unnormalised: One memorable incident involved a major audit. The company brought in Mr. Kapoor, the Chief Auditor from a big 4 firm. Mr. Kapoor was known for his meticulousness and his sharp questioning. He was addressed with a formality that bordered on comical – "Mr. Kapoor, Sir," was a constant refrain. He uncovered some discrepancies that led to a lot of restructuring in the department.

He always made sure to address employees by their names and was known to remember small details about everyone. I once heard him mention to Mr. Sharma that he remembers that his daughter was doing very well in her academics.

unnormalised: Towards the end of my internship, Mr. Sharma called me into his office. He offered me a full-time position, a junior role in the finance department. "You have potential," he said, a rare compliment. "Don't worry about the title. Focus on learning, on growing. The titles will come eventually." As I stepped out into the Mumbai rain, I knew that I had learned more than just finance. I had learned about the nuances of corporate life, the importance of respect, and the enduring power of hard work. And perhaps, most importantly, that the real value lay not in the title, but in the journey. He told me that if I wanted to move up the Corporate ladder I will have to first learn under him as Junior Manager. And if I excel he would nominate me for promotion to Assistant Manager.
